qas.question: Who was called in to watch over the presidential election in 2004?

answers.text: the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) sent a team of observers to monitor the presidential elections in 2004

qas.question: Was this the only occasion the OSCE was invited to preside over a presidential election?

answers.text: It was the first time the OSCE had sent observers to a U.S. presidential election, although they had been invited in the past.

qas.question: What were the findings of the OSCE team?

answers.text: mostly met the OSCE commitments included in the 1990 Copenhagen Document

qas.question: What type of values did the OSCE determine were adhered to during the election process?

plausible_answers.text: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE)

qas.question: What group was invited to the US by the public in 1990?
Why did OSCE come to the US in 1990?
Who did the OSCE send to the US in 1990?
How many times had the OSCE been to the US before 1990?
What was issued by the OSCE in 1990 on the election?

context: At the invitation of the United States government, <a0_0>the <b4_0>Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE)<b4_0/> sent <b6_0>a team of observers<b6_0/> <b5_0>to monitor the presidential elections<b5_0/> in 2004<a0_0/>. <a1_0><b7_0>It was the first time<b7_0/> the OSCE had sent observers to a U.S. presidential election, although they had been invited in the past.<a1_0/> In September 2004 the OSCE issued <b8_0>a report<b8_0/> on U.S. electoral processes and the election final report. The report reads: "The November 2, 2004 elections in the United States <a2_0>mostly met the OSCE commitments included in the 1990 Copenhagen Document<a2_0/>. They were conducted in an environment that reflects a <a3_0>long-standing democratic tradition<a3_0/>, including institutions governed by the rule of law, free and generally professional media, and a civil society intensively engaged in the election process. There was exceptional public interest in the two leading presidential candidates and the issues raised by their respective campaigns, as well as in the election process itself."
